question_title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before May 1, 2026?
summary: North Korea is unlikely to conduct a nuclear test before May 1, 2026. While Tunnel No. 3 at Punggye-ri has been ready since 2022 and NK is technically capable of testing at any time, the last nuclear test was in September 2017 (8+ years ago), and satellite imagery as of November 2025 showed no signs of imminent test preparations. NK's current focus is on missile testing and an upcoming party congress. The historical base rate is ~2.7%/month, but the prolonged period of readiness without testing reveals a strong political preference against nuclear testing at this time. The 3-month window is short and "Nothing Ever Happens" applies strongly.

factors.description: NK has been test-ready since 2022 but hasn't conducted a nuclear test in 8+ years, revealing strong political preference against testing despite technical capability
November 2025 satellite imagery of Punggye-ri Tunnel No. 3 shows no vehicles, human activity, instruments, power lines, or cables — no signs of imminent test preparations
NK is focused on missile testing (hypersonic, cruise, rocket launchers) and upcoming party congress — nuclear testing not the current priority
Previous Metaculus questions on NK nuclear test (before 2025, before 2026) both resolved No, establishing pattern of non-occurrence
Base rate of ~2.7% per month gives ~8% over 3 months, providing a floor for probability
Kim Jong Un planning to unveil nuclear force expansion at party congress; escalating rhetoric about strategic deterrent could precede a test
US Intelligence Community assesses NK is 'probably prepared to conduct a nuclear test'; Russia providing diplomatic cover reduces international costs
Short 3-month window significantly limits probability; nuclear test decisions involve months of political deliberation and visible logistical preparation
